thread.title: City adds vendors, show space for Italian Fest
thread.title_full: City adds vendors, show space for Italian Fest - Sun Sentinel

author: Marci Shatzman
title: City adds vendors, show space for Italian Fest
text:
After close to 8,000 people turned out for the first Italian Fest last year, the city of Boca Raton has added more food and wine vendors and expanded the footprint to close off Federal Highway in front of Sanborn Square for the party from 4 to 10 p.m. Feb. 25.
"We'll have 20 food vendors and multiple bars; last year we had one, this year we have three," said Ruby Childers, the city's downtown manager. "We wanted to make sure the lines are reasonable and there are plenty of options and areas for people to get their food and beverage.
"Everything will be concentrated in Sanborn. We expanded it logistically, so we anticipate it will be as or even more popular this year," she added.
Admission is free for the event and a live stage show on the city's showmobile. Vendors will charge for what Childers called "traditional Italian food," including pizza, sausage and peppers, ziti, calzones, calamari and cappuccino to wash down the cannolis.
"We're highlighting Tucci's pizza in Sanborn Square," said Arlene Cheeks, downtown/land records coordinator.
Italian wine, beer and cocktails will also be for sale including Peroni Nastro Azzurro, Moretti and Moretti La Rossa beers: Conte Priola Pinot Grigio, Voga Moscato, LaMarca Prosecco, Tesoro Della Regina Chianti and Fontale Sangiovese Rubicone wine and Negroni, Bellini and Aperol Spritz cocktails, according to the city.

Children's carnival activities will include small rides and face painting.
"For photo opps we'll have a gladiator and two foot soldiers on hand," Childers said.
The city will close Federal Highway from Palmetto Park Road to Northeast Second Street for the showmobile for the duration of the event. Marco Capoccia, who also does lead vocals with Ray Massa's EuroRythms, will emcee again and introduce that group, Tre Bella and Frank Sinatra tribute singer Frank Todaro.
Aaron Caruso is the new entertainer in the lineup. He opened for the late Joan Rivers and he pays tribute to the famous opera tenor Enrico Caruso.
"Caruso is a huge lover of Caruso and he's a phenomenal singer and has a great personality, he's funny and a good entertainer," Capoccia said.
Tre Bella is a New York-based trio that's known for its three-part harmony. They sing in Italian and English, singer JoAnn Robertozzi said in an email after their gig on a Holland America cruise.
"We have had guest appearances on cruise ships, TV shows and performing arts centers, in addition to headlining at Italian festivals around the country from Boston to Los Angeles," she said.
Tre Bella will open the show from 4 to 5:45 p.m. There's a 15-minute opening ceremony. The EuroRhythms will perform from 6 to 8 p.m., Caruso from 8 to 9:30 p.m. and Todaro from 9:30 to 10 p.m., according to Capoccia.
Free parking is available at City Hall, 201 W. Palmetto Park Road; the Downtown Library, 400 NW Boca Raton Blvd.; and other locations downtown where signage is featured, according to the city.
